trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn about using the command-line tools for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure using the Azure CLI asm mode.
trans-unit.target: Learn about using the command-line tools for Mac, Linux, and Windows to manage Azure using the Azure CLI asm mode.

trans-unit.source: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management
trans-unit.target: Using the Azure CLI for Mac, Linux, and Windows with Azure Service Management

trans-unit.source: This topic describes how to use the Azure CLI in the asm mode to create, manage, and delete services on the command line of Mac, Linux, and Windows computers.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes how to use the Azure CLI in the asm mode to create, manage, and delete services on the command line of Mac, Linux, and Windows computers.

trans-unit.source: This functionality is similar to that provided by the Windows PowerShell Service Management cmdlets that are installed with the Azure SDKs for .NET, Node.JS, and PHP.
trans-unit.target: This functionality is similar to that provided by the Windows PowerShell Service Management cmdlets that are installed with the Azure SDKs for .NET, Node.JS, and PHP.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure services with the asm mode is conceptually similar to thinking of individual Azure concepts and services like Websites, Virtual Machines, Virtual Networks, Storage, and so on.
trans-unit.target: Using Azure services with the asm mode is conceptually similar to thinking of individual Azure concepts and services like Websites, Virtual Machines, Virtual Networks, Storage, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Richer functionality with a logically grouped and hierarchical model of resources is available on the command line using the arm mode.
trans-unit.target: Richer functionality with a logically grouped and hierarchical model of resources is available on the command line using the arm mode.

trans-unit.source: To switch to that mode, see <link><linkText>Using the Azure Command-Line Interface with the Resource Manager</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To switch to that mode, see <link><linkText>Using the Azure Command-Line Interface with the Resource Manager</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Install and Configure the Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Install and Configure the Azure Command-Line Interface</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Optional parameters are shown in square brackets (for example, [parameter]).
trans-unit.target: Optional parameters are shown in square brackets (for example, [parameter]).

trans-unit.source: All other parameters are required.
trans-unit.target: All other parameters are required.

trans-unit.source: In addition to command-specific optional parameters documented here, there are three optional parameters that can be used to display detailed output such as request options and status codes.
trans-unit.target: In addition to command-specific optional parameters documented here, there are three optional parameters that can be used to display detailed output such as request options and status codes.

trans-unit.source: The -v parameter provides verbose output, and the -vv parameter provides even more detailed verbose output.
trans-unit.target: The -v parameter provides verbose output, and the -vv parameter provides even more detailed verbose output.

trans-unit.source: The --json option will output the result in raw json format.
trans-unit.target: The --json option will output the result in raw json format.

trans-unit.source: Setting the asm mode
trans-unit.target: Setting the asm mode

trans-unit.source: Currently the Service Management mode is enabled by default when you first install the CLI.
trans-unit.target: Currently the Service Management mode is enabled by default when you first install the CLI.

trans-unit.source: If you need to, use the following command to enable Azure CLI Service Management commands.
trans-unit.target: If you need to, use the following command to enable Azure CLI Service Management commands.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Resource Manager mode and Azure Service Management mode are mutually exclusive.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Resource Manager mode and Azure Service Management mode are mutually exclusive.

trans-unit.source: That is, resources created in one mode cannot be managed from the other mode.
trans-unit.target: That is, resources created in one mode cannot be managed from the other mode.

trans-unit.source: Manage your account information and publish settings
trans-unit.target: Manage your account information and publish settings

trans-unit.source: Your Azure subscription information is used by the tool to connect to your account.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure subscription information is used by the tool to connect to your account.

trans-unit.source: This information can be obtained from the Azure portal in a publish settings file as described here.
trans-unit.target: This information can be obtained from the Azure portal in a publish settings file as described here.

trans-unit.source: You can import the publish settings file as a persistent local configuration setting that the tool will use for subsequent operations.
trans-unit.target: You can import the publish settings file as a persistent local configuration setting that the tool will use for subsequent operations.

trans-unit.source: You only need to import your publish settings once.
trans-unit.target: You only need to import your publish settings once.

trans-unit.source: account download [options]
trans-unit.target: account download [options]

trans-unit.source: This command launches a browser to download your .publishsettings file from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: This command launches a browser to download your .publishsettings file from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: account import [options]
trans-unit.target: account import [options]

trans-unit.source: This command imports a publishsettings file or certificate so that it can be used by the tool going forward.
trans-unit.target: This command imports a publishsettings file or certificate so that it can be used by the tool going forward.

trans-unit.source: The publishsettings file can contain details (that is, subscription name and ID) about more than one subscription.
trans-unit.target: The publishsettings file can contain details (that is, subscription name and ID) about more than one subscription.

trans-unit.source: When you import the publishsettings file, the first subscription is used as the default description.
trans-unit.target: When you import the publishsettings file, the first subscription is used as the default description.

trans-unit.source: To use a different subscription, run the following command.
trans-unit.target: To use a different subscription, run the following command.

trans-unit.source: <html></html>~$ azure config set subscription <other-subscription-id><html></html>
trans-unit.target: <html></html>~$ azure config set subscription <other-subscription-id><html></html>

trans-unit.source: account clear [options]
trans-unit.target: account clear [options]

trans-unit.source: This command removes the stored publishsettings that have been imported.
trans-unit.target: This command removes the stored publishsettings that have been imported.

trans-unit.source: Use this command if you're finished using the tool on this machine and want to assure that the tool cannot be used with your account going forward.
trans-unit.target: Use this command if you're finished using the tool on this machine and want to assure that the tool cannot be used with your account going forward.

trans-unit.source: account list [options]
trans-unit.target: account list [options]

trans-unit.source: List the imported subscriptions
trans-unit.target: List the imported subscriptions

trans-unit.source: account set [options]
trans-unit.target: account set [options]

trans-unit.source: Set the current subscription
trans-unit.target: Set the current subscription

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage your affinity groups
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your affinity groups

trans-unit.source: account affinity-group list [options]
trans-unit.target: account affinity-group list [options]

trans-unit.source: This command lists your Azure affinity groups.
trans-unit.target: This command lists your Azure affinity groups.

trans-unit.source: Affinity groups can be set when a group of virtual machines spans multiple physical machines.
trans-unit.target: Affinity groups can be set when a group of virtual machines spans multiple physical machines.

trans-unit.source: The affinity group specifies that the physical machines should be as close to each other as possible, to reduce network latency.
trans-unit.target: The affinity group specifies that the physical machines should be as close to each other as possible, to reduce network latency.

trans-unit.source: account affinity-group create [options]
trans-unit.target: account affinity-group create [options]

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new affinity group
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new affinity group

trans-unit.source: account affinity-group show [options]
trans-unit.target: account affinity-group show [options]

trans-unit.source: This command shows the details of the affinity group
trans-unit.target: This command shows the details of the affinity group

trans-unit.source: account affinity-group delete [options]
trans-unit.target: account affinity-group delete [options]

trans-unit.source: This command deletes the specified affinity group
trans-unit.target: This command deletes the specified affinity group

trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your account environment

trans-unit.target: account env list [options]

trans-unit.target: List of the account environments

trans-unit.target: This command adds an environment to the account

trans-unit.source: **account env set <link><linkText>options[environment]</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **account env set <link><linkText>options[environment]</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machines

trans-unit.source: The following diagram shows how Azure virtual machines are hosted in the production deployment environment of an Azure cloud service.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram shows how Azure virtual machines are hosted in the production deployment environment of an Azure cloud service.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Technical Diagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Technical Diagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: create-new creates the drive in blob storage (that is, e:\ in the diagram); attach attaches an already created but unattached disk to a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: create-new creates the drive in blob storage (that is, e:\ in the diagram); attach attaches an already created but unattached disk to a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: vm create [options] [password]
trans-unit.target: vm create [options] [password]

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: By default, each virtual machine (vm) is created in its own cloud service; however, you can specify that a virtual machine should be added to an existing cloud service through use of the -c option as documented here.
trans-unit.target: By default, each virtual machine (vm) is created in its own cloud service; however, you can specify that a virtual machine should be added to an existing cloud service through use of the -c option as documented here.

trans-unit.source: The vm create command, like the Azure portal, only creates virtual machines in the production deployment environment.
trans-unit.target: The vm create command, like the Azure portal, only creates virtual machines in the production deployment environment.

trans-unit.source: There is no option to create a virtual machine in the staging deployment environment of a cloud service.
trans-unit.target: There is no option to create a virtual machine in the staging deployment environment of a cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If your subscription does not have an existing Azure storage account, the command creates one.
trans-unit.target: If your subscription does not have an existing Azure storage account, the command creates one.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a location through the --location parameter, or you can specify an affinity group through the --affinity-group parameter.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a location through the --location parameter, or you can specify an affinity group through the --affinity-group parameter.

trans-unit.source: If neither is provided, you are prompted to provide one from a list of valid locations.
trans-unit.target: If neither is provided, you are prompted to provide one from a list of valid locations.

trans-unit.source: The supplied password must be 8-123 characters long and meet the password complexity requirements of the operating system that you are using for this virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The supplied password must be 8-123 characters long and meet the password complexity requirements of the operating system that you are using for this virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If you anticipate the need to use SSH to manage a deployed Linux virtual machine (as is usually the case), you must enable SSH via the -e option when you create the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: If you anticipate the need to use SSH to manage a deployed Linux virtual machine (as is usually the case), you must enable SSH via the -e option when you create the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: It is not possible enable SSH after the virtual machine has been created.
trans-unit.target: It is not possible enable SSH after the virtual machine has been created.

trans-unit.source: Windows virtual machines can enable RDP later by adding port 3389 as an endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Windows virtual machines can enable RDP later by adding port 3389 as an endpoint.

trans-unit.source: The following optional parameters are supported for this command:
trans-unit.target: The following optional parameters are supported for this command:

trans-unit.source: -c, --connect create the virtual machine inside an already created deployment in a hosting service.
trans-unit.target: -c, --connect create the virtual machine inside an already created deployment in a hosting service.

trans-unit.source: If -vmname is not used with this option, the name of the new virtual machine will be generated automatically.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: If -vmname is not used with this option, the name of the new virtual machine will be generated automatically.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: -n, --vm-name Specify the name of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -n, --vm-name Specify the name of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This parameter takes hosting service name by default.
trans-unit.target: This parameter takes hosting service name by default.

trans-unit.source: If -vmname is not specified, the name for the new virtual machine is generated as <service-name><id>, where <id> is the number of existing virtual machines in the service plus 1 For example, if you use this command to add a new virtual machine to a hosting service MyService that has one existing virtual machine, the new virtual machine is named MyService2.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: If -vmname is not specified, the name for the new virtual machine is generated as <service-name><id>, where <id> is the number of existing virtual machines in the service plus 1 For example, if you use this command to add a new virtual machine to a hosting service MyService that has one existing virtual machine, the new virtual machine is named MyService2.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: -u, --blob-url Specify the target blob storage URL at which to create the virtual machine system disk.
trans-unit.target: -u, --blob-url Specify the target blob storage URL at which to create the virtual machine system disk.

trans-unit.source: -z, --vm-size Specify the size of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -z, --vm-size Specify the size of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Valid values are:
trans-unit.target: Valid values are:

trans-unit.source: "ExtraSmall", "Small", "Medium", "Large", "ExtraLarge", "A5", "A6", "A7", "A8", "A9", "A10", "A11", "Basic_A0", "Basic_A1", "Basic_A2", "Basic_A3", "Basic_A4", "Standard_D1", "Standard_D2", "Standard_D3", "Standard_D4", "Standard_D11", "Standard_D12", "Standard_D13", "Standard_D14", "Standard_DS1", "Standard_DS2", "Standard_DS3", "Standard_DS4", "Standard_DS11", "Standard_DS12", "Standard_DS13", "Standard_DS14", "Standard_G1", "Standard_G2", "Standard_G3", "Standard_G4", "Standard_G55".
trans-unit.target: "ExtraSmall", "Small", "Medium", "Large", "ExtraLarge", "A5", "A6", "A7", "A8", "A9", "A10", "A11", "Basic_A0", "Basic_A1", "Basic_A2", "Basic_A3", "Basic_A4", "Standard_D1", "Standard_D2", "Standard_D3", "Standard_D4", "Standard_D11", "Standard_D12", "Standard_D13", "Standard_D14", "Standard_DS1", "Standard_DS2", "Standard_DS3", "Standard_DS4", "Standard_DS11", "Standard_DS12", "Standard_DS13", "Standard_DS14", "Standard_G1", "Standard_G2", "Standard_G3", "Standard_G4", "Standard_G55".

trans-unit.source: The default value is "Small".
trans-unit.target: The default value is "Small".

trans-unit.source: -r Adds RDP connectivity to a Windows virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -r Adds RDP connectivity to a Windows virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: -e, --ssh Adds SSH connectivity to a Windows virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -e, --ssh Adds SSH connectivity to a Windows virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: -t, --ssh-cert Specifies the SSH certificate.
trans-unit.target: -t, --ssh-cert Specifies the SSH certificate.

trans-unit.source: -s The subscription
trans-unit.target: -s The subscription

trans-unit.source: -o, --community The specified image is a community image
trans-unit.target: -o, --community The specified image is a community image

trans-unit.source: -w The virtual network name
trans-unit.target: -w The virtual network name

trans-unit.source: -l, --location specifies the location (for example, "North Central US").
trans-unit.target: -l, --location specifies the location (for example, "North Central US").

trans-unit.source: -a, --affinity-group specifies the affinity group.
trans-unit.target: -a, --affinity-group specifies the affinity group.

trans-unit.source: -w, --virtual-network-name Specify the virtual network on which to add the new virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -w, --virtual-network-name Specify the virtual network on which to add the new virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Virtual networks can be set up and managed from the Azure portal.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: Virtual networks can be set up and managed from the Azure portal.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: -b, --subnet-names Specifies the subnet names to assign the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: -b, --subnet-names Specifies the subnet names to assign the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: In this example, MSFT__Win2K8R2SP1-120514-1520-141205-01-en-us-30GB is an image provided by the platform.
trans-unit.target: In this example, MSFT__Win2K8R2SP1-120514-1520-141205-01-en-us-30GB is an image provided by the platform.

trans-unit.source: For more information about operating system images, see vm image list.
trans-unit.target: For more information about operating system images, see vm image list.

trans-unit.source: vm create-from
trans-unit.target: vm create-from

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new Azure virtual machine from a JSON role file.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new Azure virtual machine from a JSON role file.

trans-unit.source: vm list [options]
trans-unit.target: vm list [options]

trans-unit.source: This command lists Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This command lists Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.
trans-unit.target: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.

trans-unit.source: vm location list [options]
trans-unit.target: vm location list [options]

trans-unit.source: This command lists all available Azure account locations.
trans-unit.target: This command lists all available Azure account locations.

trans-unit.source: vm show [options]
trans-unit.target: vm show [options]

trans-unit.source: This command shows details about an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command shows details about an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.
trans-unit.target: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.

trans-unit.source: vm delete [options]
trans-unit.target: vm delete [options]

trans-unit.source: This command deletes an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command deletes an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: By default, this command does not delete the Azure blob from which the operating system disk and the data disk are created.
trans-unit.target: By default, this command does not delete the Azure blob from which the operating system disk and the data disk are created.

trans-unit.source: To delete the blob as well as the virtual machine on which it is based, specify the -b option.
trans-unit.target: To delete the blob as well as the virtual machine on which it is based, specify the -b option.

trans-unit.source: vm start [options]
trans-unit.target: vm start [options]

trans-unit.source: This command starts an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command starts an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: vm restart [options]
trans-unit.target: vm restart [options]

trans-unit.source: This command restarts an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command restarts an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: vm shutdown [options]
trans-unit.target: vm shutdown [options]

trans-unit.source: This command shuts down an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command shuts down an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You may use the -p option to specify that the compute resource not be released on shutdown.
trans-unit.target: You may use the -p option to specify that the compute resource not be released on shutdown.

trans-unit.source: vm capture
trans-unit.target: vm capture

trans-unit.source: This command captures an Azure virtual machine image.
trans-unit.target: This command captures an Azure virtual machine image.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine image can only be captured if the virtual machine state is Stopped.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine image can only be captured if the virtual machine state is Stopped.

trans-unit.source: Shutdown the virtual machine before continuing.
trans-unit.target: Shutdown the virtual machine before continuing.

trans-unit.target: vm export [options]

trans-unit.source: This command exports an Azure virtual machine image to a file
trans-unit.target: This command exports an Azure virtual machine image to a file

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine endpoints
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine endpoints

trans-unit.source: The following diagram shows the architecture of a typical deployment of multiple instances of a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The following diagram shows the architecture of a typical deployment of multiple instances of a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Note that in this example port 3389 is open on each virtual machine (for RDP access), and there is also an internal IP address (for example, 168.55.11.1) on each virtual machine that is used by the load balancer to route traffic to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Note that in this example port 3389 is open on each virtual machine (for RDP access), and there is also an internal IP address (for example, 168.55.11.1) on each virtual machine that is used by the load balancer to route traffic to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This internal IP address can also be used for communication between virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This internal IP address can also be used for communication between virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>azurenetworkdiagram</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>azurenetworkdiagram</linkText>

trans-unit.source: External requests to virtual machines go through a load balancer.
trans-unit.target: External requests to virtual machines go through a load balancer.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, requests cannot be specified against a particular virtual machine on deployments with multiple virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, requests cannot be specified against a particular virtual machine on deployments with multiple virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: For deployments with multiple virtual machines, port mapping must be configured between the virtual machines (vm-port) and the load balancer (lb-port).
trans-unit.target: For deployments with multiple virtual machines, port mapping must be configured between the virtual machines (vm-port) and the load balancer (lb-port).

trans-unit.source: vm endpoint create [vm-port]
trans-unit.target: vm endpoint create [vm-port]

trans-unit.source: This command creates a virtual machine endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a virtual machine endpoint.

trans-unit.source: You may also use -u or --enable-direct-server-return to specify whether to enable direct server return on this endpoint, disabled by default.
trans-unit.target: You may also use -u or --enable-direct-server-return to specify whether to enable direct server return on this endpoint, disabled by default.

trans-unit.target: vm endpoint create-multiple [options] [:[:[:[:[:[:[:[:]]]]]]]] {1-*}

trans-unit.target: Create multiple vm endpoints.

trans-unit.target: vm endpoint delete [options]

trans-unit.target: This command deletes a virtual machine endpoint.

trans-unit.target: vm endpoint list

trans-unit.target: This command lists all virtual machine endpoints.

trans-unit.target: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.

trans-unit.target: vm endpoint update [options]

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine images
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine images

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine images are captures of already configured virtual machines that can be replicated as required.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine images are captures of already configured virtual machines that can be replicated as required.

trans-unit.source: vm image list [options]
trans-unit.target: vm image list [options]

trans-unit.source: This command gets a list of virtual machine images.
trans-unit.target: This command gets a list of virtual machine images.

trans-unit.source: There are three types of images: images created by Microsoft, which are prefixed with "MSFT", images created by third parties, which are usually prefixed with the name of the vendor, and images you create.
trans-unit.target: There are three types of images: images created by Microsoft, which are prefixed with "MSFT", images created by third parties, which are usually prefixed with the name of the vendor, and images you create.

trans-unit.source: To create images, you can either capture an existing virtual machine or create an image from a custom .vhd uploaded to blob storage.
trans-unit.target: To create images, you can either capture an existing virtual machine or create an image from a custom .vhd uploaded to blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using a custom .vhd, see vm image create.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using a custom .vhd, see vm image create.

trans-unit.source: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.
trans-unit.target: The --json option specifies that the results are returned in raw JSON format.

trans-unit.source: vm image show [options]
trans-unit.target: vm image show [options]

trans-unit.source: This command shows the details of a virtual machine image.
trans-unit.target: This command shows the details of a virtual machine image.

trans-unit.source: vm image delete [options]
trans-unit.target: vm image delete [options]

trans-unit.source: This command deletes a virtual machine image.
trans-unit.target: This command deletes a virtual machine image.

trans-unit.source: vm image create [source-path]
trans-unit.target: vm image create [source-path]

trans-unit.source: This command creates a virtual machine image.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a virtual machine image.

trans-unit.source: Your custom .vhd files are uploaded to blob storage, and then the virtual machine image is created from there.
trans-unit.target: Your custom .vhd files are uploaded to blob storage, and then the virtual machine image is created from there.

trans-unit.source: You then use this virtual machine image to create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: You then use this virtual machine image to create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The Location and OS parameters are required.
trans-unit.target: The Location and OS parameters are required.

trans-unit.source: Some systems impose per-process file descriptor limits.
trans-unit.target: Some systems impose per-process file descriptor limits.

trans-unit.source: If this limit is exceeded, the tool displays a file descriptor limit error.
trans-unit.target: If this limit is exceeded, the tool displays a file descriptor limit error.

trans-unit.source: You can run the command again using the -p <number> parameter to reduce the maximum number of parallel uploads.
trans-unit.target: You can run the command again using the -p <number> parameter to reduce the maximum number of parallel uploads.

trans-unit.source: The default maximum number of parallel uploads is 96.
trans-unit.target: The default maximum number of parallel uploads is 96.

trans-unit.source: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine data disks
trans-unit.target: Commands to manage your Azure virtual machine data disks

trans-unit.source: Data disks are .vhd files in blob storage that can be used by a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Data disks are .vhd files in blob storage that can be used by a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how data disks are deployed to blob storage, see the Azure technical diagram shown earlier.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how data disks are deployed to blob storage, see the Azure technical diagram shown earlier.

trans-unit.source: The commands for attaching data disks (azure vm disk attach and azure vm disk attach-new) assign a Logical Unit Number (LUN) to the attached data disk, as required by the SCSI protocol.
trans-unit.target: The commands for attaching data disks (azure vm disk attach and azure vm disk attach-new) assign a Logical Unit Number (LUN) to the attached data disk, as required by the SCSI protocol.

trans-unit.source: The first data disk attached to a virtual machine is assigned LUN 0, the next is assigned LUN 1, and so on.
trans-unit.target: The first data disk attached to a virtual machine is assigned LUN 0, the next is assigned LUN 1, and so on.

trans-unit.source: When you detach a data disk with the azure vm disk detach command, use the <lun> parameter to indicate which disk to detach.
trans-unit.target: When you detach a data disk with the azure vm disk detach command, use the <lun> parameter to indicate which disk to detach.

trans-unit.source: Note that you should always detach data disks in reverse order, starting with the highest-numbered LUN that has been assigned.
trans-unit.target: Note that you should always detach data disks in reverse order, starting with the highest-numbered LUN that has been assigned.

trans-unit.source: The Linux SCSI layer does not support detaching a lower-numbered LUN while a higher-numbered LUN is still attached.
trans-unit.target: The Linux SCSI layer does not support detaching a lower-numbered LUN while a higher-numbered LUN is still attached.

trans-unit.source: For example, you should not detach LUN 0 if LUN 1 is still attached.
trans-unit.target: For example, you should not detach LUN 0 if LUN 1 is still attached.

trans-unit.target: vm disk show [options]

trans-unit.target: This command shows details about an Azure disk.

trans-unit.target: **vm disk list <link><linkText>options[vm-name]</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: This command lists Azure disks, or disks attached to a specified virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This command lists Azure disks, or disks attached to a specified virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: If it is run with a virtual machine name parameter, it returns all disks attached to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: If it is run with a virtual machine name parameter, it returns all disks attached to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Lun 1 is created with the virtual machine, and any other listed disks are attached separately.
trans-unit.target: Lun 1 is created with the virtual machine, and any other listed disks are attached separately.

trans-unit.source: Executing this command without a virtual machine name parameter returns all disks.
trans-unit.target: Executing this command without a virtual machine name parameter returns all disks.

trans-unit.target: vm disk delete [options]

trans-unit.target: The disk must be detached from the virtual machine before it is deleted.

trans-unit.source: vm disk create [source-path]
trans-unit.target: vm disk create [source-path]

trans-unit.source: This command uploads and registers an Azure disk.
trans-unit.target: This command uploads and registers an Azure disk.

trans-unit.source: --blob-url, --location, or --affinity-group must be specified.
trans-unit.target: --blob-url, --location, or --affinity-group must be specified.

trans-unit.source: If you use this command with [source-path], the .vhd file specified is uploaded and a new image is created.
trans-unit.target: If you use this command with [source-path], the .vhd file specified is uploaded and a new image is created.

trans-unit.source: You can then attach this image to a virtual machine by using vm disk attach.
trans-unit.target: You can then attach this image to a virtual machine by using vm disk attach.

trans-unit.target: Some systems impose per-process file descriptor limits.

trans-unit.target: vm disk attach-new [blob-url]

trans-unit.target: This command returns mobile service logs, filtering out all log types but error.

trans-unit.target: This command supports the following additional options:

trans-unit.source: **-r * or *--query **: Executes the specified log query.
trans-unit.target: **-r * or *--query **: Executes the specified log query.

trans-unit.target: **-t * or *--type **: Filter the returned logs by entry , which can be information, warning, or error.

trans-unit.source: **-k * or *--skip **: Skips the number of rows specified by .
trans-unit.target: **-k * or *--skip **: Skips the number of rows specified by .

trans-unit.source: **-p * or *--top **: Returns a specific number of rows, specified by .
trans-unit.target: **-p * or *--top **: Returns a specific number of rows, specified by .

trans-unit.source: The --query parameter takes precedence over --type, --skip, and --top.
trans-unit.target: The --query parameter takes precedence over --type, --skip, and --top.

trans-unit.source: This command regenerates the mobile service application key.
trans-unit.target: This command regenerates the mobile service application key.

trans-unit.source: Key types are master and application.
trans-unit.target: Key types are master and application.

trans-unit.source: When you regenerate keys, clients that use the old key may be unable to access your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: When you regenerate keys, clients that use the old key may be unable to access your mobile service.

trans-unit.target: This command supports the following additional options:

You can also use the **-f * or *--file ** parameter to specify a different filename and path to the file that contains the script to register.

trans-unit.target: **mobile job create <link><linkText>options[servicename]</linkText><title></title></link> [jobname]**

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new job named getUpdates that is scheduled to run hourly.
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new job named getUpdates that is scheduled to run hourly.

trans-unit.source: This command supports the following additional options:
trans-unit.target: This command supports the following additional options:

trans-unit.source: **-i * or *--interval **: The job interval, as an integer; the default value is 15.
trans-unit.target: **-i * or *--interval **: The job interval, as an integer; the default value is 15.

trans-unit.source: **-u * or *--intervalUnit **: The unit for the interval, which can be one of the following values:
trans-unit.target: **-u * or *--intervalUnit **: The unit for the interval, which can be one of the following values:

trans-unit.source: minute (default)
trans-unit.target: minute (default)

trans-unit.source: hour
trans-unit.target: hour

trans-unit.source: day
trans-unit.target: day

trans-unit.source: month
trans-unit.target: month

trans-unit.source: none (on-demand jobs)
trans-unit.target: none (on-demand jobs)

trans-unit.source: **-t * *--startTime ** The start time of the first run for the script, in ISO format; the default value is now.
trans-unit.target: **-t * *--startTime ** The start time of the first run for the script, in ISO format; the default value is now.

trans-unit.source: New jobs are created in a disabled state because a script must still be uploaded.
trans-unit.target: New jobs are created in a disabled state because a script must still be uploaded.

trans-unit.source: Use the mobile script upload command to upload a script and the mobile job update command to enable the job.
trans-unit.target: Use the mobile script upload command to upload a script and the mobile job update command to enable the job.

trans-unit.target: **mobile scale change <link><linkText>options[servicename]</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.target: This command supports the following additional options:
